title: 104_s1905
content: The Act titled "Campaign Finance Reform Commission Act of 1996" establishes a commission. The "Federal Election Law Reform Commission" is established with 8 members appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, including a retired Federal judge and a former Member of Congress. The Federal Election Law Reform Commission is established with appointments made by various leaders, including members from the academic community, retired Federal judges, former Members of Congress, and the President. The Federal Election Law Reform Commission members appointed by various leaders shall jointly appoint 2 members who have not held any elected or appointed public office in the past 10 years. Qualifications for appointment include not having held a position under schedule C of title 5 of the Code of Federal Regulations in the past 10 years. The Federal Election Law Reform Commission appoints members with specific qualifications, including not having held certain government positions in the past 10 years. Additionally, no more than 3 members can be affiliated with the same political party. The Federal Election Law Reform Commission appoints members with specific qualifications, including financial disclosure within 60 days of appointment. The chairperson and vice chairperson must be from different political parties. The Federal Election Law Reform Commission appoints members for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission will terminate one year after the enactment of the Act. It has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and take necessary actions to fulfill the purposes of the Act. The Commission may request information from federal agencies and use the United States mails. Members of the Commission are paid based on the Executive Schedule, with the Chairperson receiving separate compensation. The Chairperson of the Commission is paid based on the Executive Schedule, with a daily rate equivalent to level III of the Executive Schedule. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director who is paid at the rate of level IV of the Executive Schedule. The executive director can also appoint additional personnel as needed. The Commission can appoint additional personnel as necessary, with pay not exceeding GS-15 level. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Chairperson can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with identifying goals for Federal campaign finance laws, evaluating the impact of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, and making recommendations to Congress. Recommendations include considering limits on campaign spending, regulating interest groups' role, and assessing other funding sources for Federal election campaigns. The Commission will report on its activities and recommend legislation to amend campaign finance laws within a year of the Act's enactment. This includes addressing issues like soft money, bundling, and independent expenditures. SEC. 4. FAST-TRACK PROCEDURES. The section outlines rules for the House of Representatives and Senate regarding the enactment of Federal election bills. It emphasizes the rulemaking power of each House and their ability to change rules. The term "Federal election bill" is defined as a bill introduced in Congress to carry out specific procedures. The Federal election bill, introduced as provided in subsection (c), must be carried out to implement the Commission's recommendations. The bill must be introduced in the House of Representatives and Senate by the Majority Leaders, and no amendments are allowed to the bill in either House. The Federal election bill must be introduced in the House and Senate by the Majority Leaders without amendments. If a committee hasn't reported the bill after 30 days, it will be automatically discharged for further consideration and placed on the calendar. If both Houses receive the same bill, the final vote will be on the bill from the other House. In the House of Representatives, a motion to proceed to consider a Federal election bill is highly privileged and can only be made on the second legislative day after announcement. Debate is limited during consideration of the bill in the House. In the House, debate on a Federal election bill is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents. The previous question is ordered for final passage without interruption. Appeals on House rules for the bill are decided without debate. In the Senate, a motion to consider a Federal election bill is privileged and not debatable, with no amendments allowed. In the Senate, debate on a Federal election bill is limited to 10 hours, divided between Majority Leader and Minority Leader. Debate on motions or appeals related to the bill is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the bill manager. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders during consideration of motions or appeals. In the Senate, debate on a Federal election bill is limited to 10 hours, divided between Majority Leader and Minority Leader. Debate on motions or appeals related to the bill is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the bill manager. Any debatable motion or appeal. A motion in the Senate to further limit debate is not debatable. A motion to recommit a Federal election bill is not in order. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Commission to carry out its duties under this Act.
